Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another It may be helpful for both of you to complete your signatures. There is much more to this choice than weight alone. Will do shortly. Eric
Posts.Title: Weight issues with prostate removal

Posts.Content: Hi Lakerat, I had my prostate removed in October of 2017. At the time I weighed 270 lbs. My height is 5'10". Along with the size of my prostate (225 grams), this made for a lengthy, ten hour surgery with an additional incision for another doctor to come in and assist. However, my recovery was uneventful and overall I am pleased with the surgery. I should add that my overall health was reasonably good going in. My suggestion would be to consult with a top notch prostate surgery specialist who has done many hundreds is not thousands of these procedures. Your urologist's reluctance may be because of a lack of experience. Do you have other health conditions which may impact your decision? Eric

Posts.Title: SRT without ADT - Quick Update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Busby I'm going to have da Vinci surgery in January. I live alone and was wondering if it's going to be difficult to recover on my own. Am I going to have to make arrangements for someone to stay with me? Hi Busby, I had my surgery October, 2017. Looking back at my experience, I would say three days I definitely needed help, two days marginal, and after that I could have managed. However I will say that for the first week it would have been very hard not to have help. You have a lot going on with the catheter, and the abdominal soreness. You're not supposed to lift anything. It can be a rough surgery so I would take all the help I could get.

Posts.Title: (Hope this is okay) Mens Health did a PCa story and I am in it

Posts.Content: Dear Vjbaba, I am in a similar position to you, having had the Lupron shot December 27th and starting radiation this coming Tues. Don't worry too much about the Lupron. For me, while I can certainly feel the effects, it is manageable. More of an inconvenience than a disaster. In terms of the treatment schedule, 38 or 40 is standard. There are clinical trials ongoing where higher doses are given on a shorter schedule, with tracking of side effects and mortality, but this is not yet the standard. Keep your chin up, you will get through this! Eric

Posts.Content: I recently had had a cat scat at Dana Farber preliminary to salvage radiation. I found out I have gallstones, arthrosclerotic changes to my spine, a small area of collapsed lung, and two incisional hernias. So nice no one seems to be concerned about any of these things, I'm not going to worry either. Eric

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I take the minimum dose of avorstatin and never noticed a problem. Doc does a liver panel regularly, of course. Keep in mind that should you encounter an unwanted effect with your first statin, your doc has a number of alternatives to try. I started taking Lipitor a little over a year ago, and I have noticed zero side effects.

Posts.Title: Statins and ultrasensitive PSA ??

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by nmguy Hi Maximus. I am almost 6 weeks post surgery. I'm the same in that I don't feel the urge to pee. I can hold a fair amount in my bladder but when I start to leak quite a bit instead of the little dribble I go pee, usually a fair amount. I have asked the same question you did about not feeling the urge to pee here a couple of times but no one has ever answered so I guess no one else has experienced this. I asked my doctor about it and he said some of the nerves may have been injured but they should heal up. So far I still don't feel a real urge to pee. That's all I know about that. I had my prostate removed on October 2, 2017. Like you, for some time I did not feel to urge to pee. My guess it is a function of the fact that you are constantly leaking so that your bladder never fills to the point that triggers the urge, and also the fact that the whole area gets pretty beat up as a result of the surgery. For me, as I healed up, I gradually regained continence and the urge to pee. The trick is to stay patient. Eric
Posts.Title: Working With Incontinence

Posts.Title: Working With Incontinence

Posts.Content: Hi Busby, welcome to the forum. As far as pain goes, everyone is different. My doctor perscribed four days worth of painkillers. I stopped after two and switched to over the counter for a couple of days more. You, however, should do whatever is necessary for yourself. If you need the pills take them until you don't need them anymore. The thing that helped me the most with pain was getting up and walking. It got the blood flowing and helped stretch out the sore muscles. You probably should try to have someone stay with you for the first couple of days after you get home from the hospital. I was pretty out of it for a couple of days. Remember you won't be able to drive while on the painkillers and you can't lift much for a while. As far as the catheter and bag, it is not difficult. Just follow the cleaning instructions to the letter. The worst part of the catheter is the pain and soreness where it moves around at the tip of the penis. The lidocaine helps a lot, and what really helps is getting it out. Good luck, you'll get through it fine. Eric
Posts.Title: My da Vinci date is January 9

Posts.Content: I am on Medicare with an excellent supplement, and if there is one upside to my prostate cancer journey it is that I haven't had to worry about paying for care. However, my medical oncologist is recommending starting Zytiga along with Lupron. If my calculations are correct, the Zytiga will cost me through my RX plan approx. $11,000.00 a year. It will be a huge struggle to pay for this. Now I am not jealous or begrudge anyone who has more means than I. Plenty have less and I am happy for what I have. But to answer the original question, it helps a lot having the means to cover whatever comes up in treatment. Eric

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor The Lab Corp lady told me it would take 72-hours (noon Monday January 8 ) for the Patient Portal to update. That was her response to me telling her I would pay her a substantial amount to guarantee a number of 0.02 or less. When I saw the message posted saying results were sent to my Doc I assumed that meant no more updating of my Patient Portal. I forgot all about the PSA blood draw yesterday because there are more painful things occurring to distract me: - our almost new and very expensive LG "French Door" refrigerator pissed out a puddle of water (sympathetic incontinence?) and is now not cooling. LG & Lowes are pointing fingers at each other as to who is responsible due to a factory warranty and Lowe's Extended Purchase Protection both being in effect. Lowe's has sent two technicians to the house and LG one and they all disagree on what to do. It has been 8-days since the 'fridge quit and the LG tech today said it will be AT LEAST January 14 noon before anyone can do anything. - Started trying to work on 2018 taxes to see if I need to make a final 1040ES payment for 2018 before January 15 BUT IRS has not finalized worksheets for 2018 mortgage deductions and TurboTax will not calculate my 2018 tax bill SO - I have enough to distract me from worrying about the minor detail of UltraSensitive PSA tests and future radiation! Very funny! It's good to focus on the important things

Posts.Title: Completed SRT

Posts.Content: Hi all, Today I got the results of the pet scan I had done last Wed. To give some background, I had RP on October 2nd of last year. Cancer was classified as 4+3, I had extracapular extensions but no invasion of surrounding tissue. My first two Psa tests were undetectable, followed by a .04, a .06 six weeks later, and a .07 six weeks after that. Given my situation, I fully expected the Pet scan to be negative, and that I would proceed into radiation and six months of hormone therapy with a good chance of cure. Unfortunately, it showed several spots of cancer in several lymph nodes near the aorta in the abdomen. My surgeon will be conferencing with my MO and my RO to determine the best course of action, but he feel that it won't be possible to radiate this area and I am looking at hormone therapy. I am knocked for a loop about this. I have learned so much on this forum so I am hoping you can advise me with anything I need to ask the doctors or any other useful information. Thanks in advance. Eric
Posts.Title: Bad news today

Posts.Title: Bad news today

Posts.Content: Thank you for all your responses and good wishes. I am being treated at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut. I had previously met with both the RO and MO and I am satisfied with their abilities. Hartford Hospital, while not a well known cancer center, has an affiliation with Sloan Kettering and seems to me to be up to date on current methods and treatments. I will not hesitate however to seek second opinions once a plan is proposed and will review the clinical trial material referenced so I can bring it up with the doctors. Once again thank you all. I will post an update when I know more. Eric

I was surprised to hear Xytiga and I welcome any thoughts. I intend to call Dr. D'amico today to set up an appointment. My brother lives outside of Boston and I can meet him for lunch.

Posts.Content: That is great news! It just shows how unpredictable this disease can be. Eric
Posts.Title: New MRI Results - MY PCa is Regressing

Posts.Content: Hi RR, Everyone is different, but at six months most are reasonably continent. In my case, like you, I seemed to be leaking constantly, going through six or seven heavy duty pull ups a day. Gradually, however, it seemed to be less and less, and at the three month point there had accumulated a lot of improvement. I think I was down to a couple of pull-ups a day. I continued to mprove and at about six months switched to a light pad every day. I am now more than a year post surgery and I still use the pad. I still drip and dribble a little, mostly when I sneeze and cough, but I am satisfied where I am. It is important to do the kegels, and it may be helpful to avoid caffeine and alcohol. I also found that if I frequently emptied my bladder, that decreased the need to change pull-ups. Wherever I went, I always carried a bag with pull-ups, some wipes and anything else I thought I'd need. Another thing you can do when you are away from home is to use a booster pad inside your pull-ups or diapers. This way after a while you can discard the pad without changing undergarment. The main thing is not to worry. You will be dry or next to dry before you know it, and you will manage things up until then. Eric
Posts.Title: Gentlemen, please talk to me about incontinence

Posts.Content: That is great news! It just shows how unpredictable this disease can be. Eric

Posts.Title: Gentlemen, please talk to me about incontinence

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mark H. Thanks for the heads up, I didn't realize that. I drink lots of coffee so volume is not the problem. And I am trying to determine if it is a problem limited to standing or if it also happens when seated (which, I am not sure that it does). You may want to rethink the coffee, at least temporarily. Caffeine can irritate the bladder and that is the last thing you need right now. You may find that you can quiet things down quite a bit by eliminating coffee.
Posts.Title: Catheter removed....now what?

Posts.Content: Hey Shanis, That is great news! It's also great that you will be testing a little less often. Until I was diagnosed, I never understood the mental and emotional toll that disease takes. Keep up the good work! Eric
Posts.Title: Back for a six month update...PSA is doing strange things

Posts.Content: AceVa, You have to have faith in your doctor, and if you don't, find a new one. You mentioned that on two occasions you asked for additional testing and were denied. Did your urologist give a reasonable explanation of why he wouldn't find the information useful? Let's hope that the biopsy is negative, however even if it is, the whole situation bears close watching, presumably by a new, highly qualified, prostate cancer experienced urologist.
Posts.Title: Biopsy was today - thoughts on if my frustration with doctor is justified?

Posts.Title: Catheter removed....now what?

Posts.Content: Maybe a hernia related to one of your incisions? A recent cat scan revealed I had two, but since they are asymtomatic, I have bigger things to worry about. Eric
Posts.Title: Stomach Pain

Posts.Content: I think that frequent urination is pretty common after RP. Your bladder and surrounding tissue have taken a real beating, and it is not surprisingly that they are pretty sensitive right now. As things heal, you will return to a more normal interval. Eric
Posts.Title: Urine retention following catheter removal ...back to "Cathy"

Posts.Content: I think that frequent urination is pretty common after RP. Your bladder and surrounding tissue have taken a real beating, and it is not surprisingly that they are pretty sensitive right now. As things heal, you will return to a more normal interval. Eric
Posts.Title: Urine retention following catheter removal ...back to "Cathy"

Posts.Content: I am in the exact same boat as you with very similar numbers. I am waiting for my latest Psa test which I took on Tues. I discussed the hormone therapy with both my radiation oncologist and my medical oncologist, and decided to do it for six months. I want the best possible chance to beat the illness.

Posts.Title: Gentlemen, please talk to me about incontinence

Posts.Content: Congratulations! I have just finished my seventh session of thirty nine. So far so good, but developed the trots today. I may have to cut down fiber or the stool softener they are having me take. I think I have the full bladder thing down, unless they are running late. Then it can turn into torture. Eric
Posts.Title: ART done...DING!

Posts.Content: Hi, Everything that is happening is completely normal. You have to remember that your bladder has taken a serious beating during your surgery. Part of your urethra was removed along with the prostate, and your bladder was moved so that the urethra could be reattached. Everything is real sensitive right now, and will be until it is healed. Because of this, you will have frequent urges to urinate. Everything will eventually settle down, although you may not be entirely the same. I find that at a year post surgery, I still have to bear down to entirely empty the bladder.
Posts.Title: Catheter removed....now what?

Posts.Content: Hi RR, Everyone is different, but at six months most are reasonably continent. In my case, like you, I seemed to be leaking constantly, going through six or seven heavy duty pull ups a day. Gradually, however, it seemed to be less and less, and at the three month point there had accumulated a lot of improvement. I think I was down to a couple of pull-ups a day. I continued to mprove and at about six months switched to a light pad every day. I am now more than a year post surgery and I still use the pad. I still drip and dribble a little, mostly when I sneeze and cough, but I am satisfied where I am. It is important to do the kegels, and it may be helpful to avoid caffeine and alcohol. I also found that if I frequently emptied my bladder, that decreased the need to change pull-ups. Wherever I went, I always carried a bag with pull-ups, some wipes and anything else I thought I'd need. Another thing you can do when you are away from home is to use a booster pad inside your pull-ups or diapers. This way after a while you can discard the pad without changing undergarment. The main thing is not to worry. You will be dry or next to dry before you know it, and you will manage things up until then. Eric
Posts.Title: Gentlemen, please talk to me about incontinence

Posts.Content: AceVa, You have to have faith in your doctor, and if you don't, find a new one. You mentioned that on two occasions you asked for additional testing and were denied. Did your urologist give a reasonable explanation of why he wouldn't find the information useful? Let's hope that the biopsy is negative, however even if it is, the whole situation bears close watching, presumably by a new, highly qualified, prostate cancer experienced urologist.
Posts.Title: Biopsy was today - thoughts on if my frustration with doctor is justified?

Posts.Content: My understanding is that the typical salvage radiation is thirty nine sessions, five days a week for approx. eight weeks. As far as traveling for the treatment, I live near Hartford, CT and had my surgery at Hartford Hospital. While I am satisfied with my surgeon and the surgery, I am not as pleased with the follow up care. I have opted to continue at Dana Farber, and assuming as I hope that salvage is in my near future, I will have it at Dana Farber even though this will entail considerable logistical issues.
Posts.Title: Frequency & number of salvage radiation sessions

Posts.Content: Hey Shanis, That is great news! It's also great that you will be testing a little less often. Until I was diagnosed, I never understood the mental and emotional toll that disease takes. Keep up the good work! Eric
Posts.Title: Back for a six month update...PSA is doing strange things

Posts.Content: My understanding is that the typical salvage radiation is thirty nine sessions, five days a week for approx. eight weeks. Posts.Title: Frequency & number of salvage radiation sessions

Posts.Content: Hi, Everything that is happening is completely normal. You have to remember that your bladder has taken a serious beating during your surgery. Part of your urethra was removed along with the prostate, and your bladder was moved so that the urethra could be reattached. Everything is real sensitive right now, and will be until it is healed. Because of this, you will have frequent urges to urinate. Everything will eventually settle down, although you may not be entirely the same. I find that at a year post surgery, I still have to bear down to entirely empty the bladder.
Posts.Title: Catheter removed....now what?

Posts.Content: Thanks, this is very useful info. Eric
Posts.Title: Refuse dangerous 'black boxed' antibiotic CIPRO. It is bad stuff...

Posts.Content: Others here are much more knowledgeable than me, but I don't believe that the .2 threshold is written in stone. Rate of rise, doubling time, etc are more important.
Posts.Title: BCR? PSA .03 1.3 years after surgery - Advice needed

Posts.Content: The reading by itself may not mean much. It is very low and may be a blip. However, I would ask for another test in four to six weeks. If you see another rise, then you need to have a discussion with yout doctor. In my situation, I had RD October of 2017. My first two PSA tests after the surgery were undetectable. In August I registered a .04. My follow up the end of September was a .06. My doctor ordered a third for the end of this month, and in the meantime had me see a radiation oncologist to set things in motion. He also ordered a pet scan, the idea being that a third rise will trigger treatment.
Posts.Title: BCR? PSA .03 1.3 years after surgery - Advice needed

Posts.Content: Others here are much more knowledgeable than me, but I don't believe that the .2 threshold is written in stone. Rate of rise, doubling time, etc are more important.

Posts.Content: Hey Sean, It sounds like everything is moving along the way it should. It took a full week for me for the drain site to stop oozing completely. The fact that you had some morning wood is great news! Keep up the good work. Eric
Posts.Title: 6 days postop

Posts.Content: Thank you for posting this. Years ago my Doctor insisted that I take 5000 mg a day. I have done so ever since. It's time to at least think about cutting back.

Posts.Content: Thank you for sharing this news. It helps me as I face the next stage of my treatment.
Posts.Title: Still Exhaling

Posts.Content: Hi Mlock, Welcome to the forum and thank you for posting your journey so far. A lot of what you said resonated with me. I too am very fortunate to have a partner of 35 years that I can depend upon. However I am so used to trying to be the strong one, that I hesitate to tell her bad news because I don't want to worry her. There is a lot to get through emotionally with a cancer diagnosis. Good luck with the surgery. With a great team on your side, I am sure you will come through with flying colors. Eric
Posts.Title: I have PCa and this is my 1st post
